Legal_Issue: Does the applicant qualify for a stay of removal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds?

Legal_Provision: R. v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration)
Evaluation_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Irreparable harm, best interests of the child, unsafe conditions in Nigeria

Assessment_Standard: Tripartite test for stay: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Evidence_Ignored: Hardships due to injury, medical treatment needs, family ties, country conditions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Violation_Type: Failure to depart after removal order
Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the criteria for a stay of removal under the IRPA?
Application_Facts: Financial ruin, inability to work, lack of medical care, danger in Nigeria, stepson's best interests
Court_Ruling: Stay granted due to serious issue, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Defendant_Behavior: Remained in Canada after removal order
Legal_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Assessment_Factor: Medical condition, financial hardship, safety concerns, family ties
Evidence_Used: Medical records, country condition reports, family relationship evidence
Application_Basis: Risk upon return, best interests of child
Evidence_Assessed: Potential danger in Nigeria, loss of medical care
Harm_Assessment: Irreparable harm including health deterioration and financial collapse
Cause_Description: Seeking to avoid removal due to personal and medical hardships
Evidence_Handling: Alleged failure to consider all H&C factors
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 44(1) - failure to comply with removal order
Jurisdictional_Issue: Enforcement of removal under Canadian immigration law
Decision_Rationale: Serious legal issues, irreparable harm, balance of convenience favors applicant
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider best interests of the child and medical needs
